Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Exploiting Prokaryotic Proteins to Improve Plant Photosynthetic Efficiency
Award.AbstractNarration: Photorespiration can account for yield losses of 25-50% in C3 plants, which include rice, wheat and soybean, three of the top four crops in terms of global grain production. Photorespiration occurs because oxygen and carbon dioxide (CO2) compete for the same acceptor molecule in photosynthesis. The process can be very simply inhibited by increasing the concentration of CO2. When CO2 is increased artificially in greenhouses or in open fields, very significant yield increases are obtained. However, artificially elevating CO2 over millions of acres of fields is not feasible. Some cyanobacteria solve this problem by confining the fixation of carbon to a structure termed a carboxysome, where localization of specific enzymes cause a concentration of CO2. Although chloroplasts, which contain the photosynthetic machinery of crops, lack carboxysomes, they evolved from cyanobacteria, which were symbiotically recruited into the ancestors of todays plants and crops. This research project will provide the foundation for a synthetic biology approach in which carboxysomes will be engineered into the chloroplasts of crop plants to enhance photosynthesis. Optimization will involve manipulating a model plant that is readily transformable and the development of an in silico model of the system to evaluate the use of different proteins and the minimal system that is needed. A multidisciplinary approach will be implemented through collaboration of four research groups, each contributing complementary expertise: carboxysome genetics and assembly (Berkeley), chloroplast and nuclear transformation (Cornell), photosynthetic systems modelling (Illinois) and physiological and biochemical characterization of the whole plant (Rothamsted, Cornell and Illinois). The project will allow postdoctoral and undergraduate trainees to gain experience in an international collaborative project (All). Research resources for comparing plant and bacterial genes will be developed for use in undergraduate education (Berkeley).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The UN Food and Agricultural Organization has forecast that the world will need 70% more food by 2050. At present rates of crop yield improvement, there will be a very significant short-fall. Innovations developed from basic scientific understanding are therefore needed to accelerate improvement. Rice and wheat, the number 1 and 2 direct sources of human calories, and soybean, the world’s most important source of vegetable protein, assimilate atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) first into a three-carbon compound – and are therefore known as C3 plants. However, they lose about 30% of yield due to a process known as photorespiration. This results because the enzyme that catalyzes CO2 uptake (Rubisco) can also react with oxygen. If oxygen is used, it results in carbon loss as carbon dioxide, counteracting photosynthesis. CO2 and oxygen compete at Rubisco, so photorespiration can be reduced by elevating CO2 concentration, and this effect is used commercially in glasshouses to raise the yield of crops, such as tomatoes. However, this is not practical with field crops. Several photosynthetic organisms have overcome photorespiration by elevating CO2 concentration at the sites were CO2 is fixed within the cell. Blue-green algae, also known as cyanobacteria, are one such organism. They have specialized structures in their cells called carboxysomes. These contain Rubisco as well as a suite of enzymes that concentrate CO2 within the carboxysome to a level sufficient to inhibit photorespiration. Chloroplasts are small green bodies within the cells of plant leaves that conduct photosynthesis. Chloroplast DNA tells us that they evolved from cyanobacteria, but unlike cyanobacteria, they lack carboxysomes and the associated enzymes. When land plants first evolved, the CO2 concentration of the atmosphere was very high and so carboxysomes may have been unnecessary. Today however they could benefit plants and given the similarity of carboxysomes and chloroplasts, re-introducing the carboxysome seems achievable, but would it really benefit crops and how much of the cyanobacterial system is necessary? Testing this directly by engineering all permutations of the cyanobacterial system components into a crop step-by-step would take many person-years to complete. Therefore, our first step was to simulate the whole system, a leaf and all its machinery for metabolizing carbon, in silico. then allowed us to simulate adding in the components of the carboxysome, and determine what parts were necessary and what gain in carbon fixation could be achieved. Because the computer can work through thousands of permutations, it is also able to predict the sequence of steps for engineering the components.

This in silico engineering of the system showed that photosynthetic rate of a mature crop canopy could be increased 60% if the entire cyanobacterial shell and six more components were added. However, it also showed that introduction of just one component, a carbon transporter, would give a 9% improvement, making it an attractive first step. From the computational work, we deduced two engineering pathways to achieve this improvement. One pathway assumes that only one component can be added at a time, and indicates that the carboxysome has to be introduced later in the sequence; early introduction could actually lower photosynthesis. The second pathway assumes that mutually-dependent components can be added simultaneously, and indicates that carboxysomes can be added immediately after carbon transporters. Both pathways produce the same end result, but the second pathway results in more improvement early in the sequence.
